title: Allamoore Formation
text:
The Allamoore Formation is a <a href="Precambrian">Precambrian</a> <a href="Formation%20%28geology%29">geologic formation</a> found in the vicinity of <a href="Van%20Horn%2C%20Texas">Van Horn, Texas</a>. The formation is notable for the well-preserved <a href="Microfossil">microfossils</a> found in <a href="chert">chert</a> beds within the formation. These may include early <a href="eukaryotes">eukaryotes</a>. Possible <a href="fossil%20burrow">fossil burrow</a>s were reported in the formation in 1995, which would push the origin of the first animals (<a href="Metazoa">Metazoa</a>) back to before 1000 million years ago. However, these have since been explained as <a href="diagenetic">diagenetic</a> structures, formed by nonbiological processes as the <a href="sediments">sediments</a> making up the formation were <a href="Compaction%20%28geology%29">compacted</a> and <a href="Lithification">lithified</a>.
Description.
The Allamoore Formation consists of blue to brown thinly <a href="Bedding%20%28geology%29">bedded</a> <a href="limestone">limestone</a> with interbedded <a href="chert">chert</a> seams. Masses of <a href="metavolcanic%20rock">metavolcanic rock</a> are also found within the formation, including metamorphosed <a href="basalts">basalts</a> and <a href="tuffs">tuffs</a> that were once <a href="lava%20flows">lava flows</a> and <a href="volcanic%20ash">volcanic ash</a> beds. The formation is exposed only in a <a href="Fold%20and%20thrust%20belt">folded belt</a> near <a href="Van%20Horn%2C%20Texas">Van Horn, Texas</a>, where <a href="tectonic">tectonic</a> process tilted the beds nearly vertical. This exposed a thickness of over of limestone beds. The formation overlies the <a href="Carrizo%20Formation">Carrizo Formation</a> and is in turn overlain by the <a href="Tumbledown%20Formation">Tumbledown Formation</a>.
The age of the Allamoore Formation is estimated at 1250 million years, based on <a href="radiometric%20dating">radiometric dating</a> of ash beds within the formation. The formation is thought to have been deposited during the <a href="Grenville%20Orogeny">Grenville Orogeny</a>, when another continent (likely Africa) collided with North America. This led to the opening of <a href="rift">rift</a> basins along the southern margin of North America, where sediments accumulated. The sediments making up the Allamoore Formation largely escaped the severe <a href="metamorphism">metamorphism</a> that affected most of the sedimentary rock laid down during the orogeny. This makes the formation a valuable window into conditions at that time.
Fossils.
The chert beds of the Allamoore Formation contain exceptionally well-preserved microfossils. These were part of mat-building communities of microbes (<a href="stromatolites">stromatolites</a>) that lived in shallow water and were occasionally exposed to air. The microorganisms were preserved in fine-grained chert shortly after their remains were buried in sediments. They appear to be mostly <a href="cyanobacteria">cyanobacteria</a>, members of the families <a href="Entophysalidaceae">Entophysalidaceae</a> and <a href="Chroococcaceae">Chroococcaceae</a>. The chert also preserves tubular remains of organisms resembling the modern "<a href="Oscillatoria">Oscillatoria</a>" and other filamentary <a href="prokaryotes">prokaryotes</a>. The chert contains well-preserved large spheroidal cells exceeding 100 microns in diameter, which may be early examples of <a href="Red%20algae">red</a> or <a href="Green%20algae">green</a> <a href="eukaryotic">eukaryotic</a> <a href="algae">algae</a>.
In 1995, a team of researchers reported the presence of sediment-filled tubes in the formation. These were interpreted as <a href="fossil%20burrow">fossil burrow</a>s of very early <a href="Metazoa">animals</a>. If confirmed, the finding would push the origin of animal life back to before 1000 million years ago. However, the structures have since been interpreted as "pseudo-traces", <a href="sedimentary%20structures">sedimentary structures</a> formed in the sediments by inorganic processes as the sediments were converted to solid rock (<a href="diagenesis">diagenesis</a>).
History of investigation.
The beds assigned to the formation were originally part of the (now-defunct) Millican Formation. They were assigned to the Allamoore Formation in 1940 by Philip B. King and named for exposures near the Allamoore Post Office.
